Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program is supporting the research of Professor Jeffrey S. Moore of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. Professor Moore's research efforts revolve around the rational design of functional macromolecular architectures. This project will continue work on the development of efficient methods for shape-persistent macrocycle synthesis by dynamic alkyne metathesis. While the preparation of shape-persistent macrocycles via dynamic covalent chemistry is an established process, product distribution is not always intuitive, and a general set of design criteria for monomers is needed. Detailed structure-property relationship studies will be undertaken to develop a deeper understanding of the role of the monomer identity on the dynamic formation of macrocycles. From these studies, a set of design rules will be developed that will generalize the conditional requirements for the efficient preparation of macrocycles under thermodynamic control. The preparation of novel arylene ethynylene macrocycles with potentially novel functionality will be a direct result of this study.

Successful development of the methodology will have an impact on the development of sensors for battlegrounds, as these macrocycles are highly sensitive to explosives and their precursors. In addition, this project will provide excellent training in advanced chemistry research to graduate students. Scientific outreach activities involving high school students, summer camps, science clubs, and unpaid scientific consulting for TV stations are also integrative parts of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome: Professor Moore’s group is developing new methods to produce functionally useful macrocyclic materials while reducing the generation of wasteful byproducts. One of these synthetic methods, termed depolymerization macrocyclization (DPMac), is advantageous over previous methods because it can be conducted on large scales and is higher yielding than previous methods. This process also has the ability to introduce diversity and systematic variations in the framework that are needed to impart sensitivity and selectivity. In addition, understanding how shape, size, and other geometric factors affect the preparation allows for targeted production of interesting macrocyclic products. These new materials are now being incorporated into field portable explosives detection devices.

 

Impact & Benefits: Not only is this method beneficial to society because it is more efficient and atom economical, it also allows for the production of useful quantities of a recently discovered sensory material for explosives detection. In collaboration with Ling Zang (University of Utah) the Moore group has shown that these materials can be processed into fluorescent fibers which can detect low levels of vapors from explosives (such as TNT). This new environmentally friendly approach to explosives sensing materials has major implications for homeland security as well as those on the front line who are targets of improvised explosive devices.

 

Background & Explanation: The Moore group is interested in creating carbon-rich materials. We are also deeply involved in developing efficient methods to construct these functional materials. A result of these efficient methods has been a greater understanding of how shape, size, and other geometric factors affect the production of these carbon-rich macrocyclic materials. This will allow future researchers to rationally design new materials with desired structure and functionality, such as macrocyclic products capable of increased selectivity and sensitivity towards explosives. NSF support has allowed a postdoctoral researcher, graduate and undergraduate students learn of the design rules that govern the creation of these interesting materials.

Modified by: Jeffrey S Moore
